awd_titl_txt: ATD: Robustness, Privacy, and Fairness in Threat Detection
awd_abstract_narration:
The project focuses on three important topics within the general context of threat detection: robustness, privacy and fairness. Robust procedures are needed for dealing with highly corrupted and noisy data. The project will consider robust generation of images and its important application to synthetic data augmentation in the presence of outliers and noise. Private procedures are needed to maintain confidentiality of individuals when collecting aggregate data that aims to serve the public interest. Differential privacy has emerged as the predominant theoretical framework for addressing such issues. The project will develop effective differentially-private algorithms for dimension reduction that are relevant to threat detection. Fair procedures are needed to avoid influences of social biases against minorities and any prejudice or favoritism towards an individual or a group based on their characteristics. This is crucial in many threat detection applications that focus on anomalies, where under-represented individuals may be unfairly profiled as anomalous and consequently threat-prone. The project will focus on fair dimension reduction algorithms that are relevant to threat detection. The resulting algorithms will be tested on different geospatial, human-dynamics and imaging datasets.

This project will support one graduate student in the first and third years and one postdoc in the second year. The project aims to develop effective algorithms and mathematical foundations relevant to the above three stated themes. The main focus of the study of robustness will be on the generation of realistic images when the training set for the generative task is corrupted, either by noise or by outliers (e.g., having images from a different class or completely corrupted images so their typical structure cannot be recognized). The project will explore an end-to-end deep neural network to robustly generate high-fidelity images under corruption without knowing the labels of the corrupted, or anomalous, data points. The main focus of the study of privacy will be on theory and algorithms for differentially private dimension reduction. Differential privacy will be obtained by incorporating a noise mechanism. The expected theory will highlight the interaction between nonconvexity, smoothness, and robustness in relation to differential privacy. The main focus of the study of fairness will be on theory and algorithms for fair dimension reduction, where fairness will be obtained by minimizing a special non-convex energy function. The theory will highlight the interaction between nonconvexity and fairness.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project aimed to develop robust methods for threat detection while addressing privacy and fairness concerns. Robustness refers to a system's ability to perform well even under challenging conditions, such as noisy or corrupted data and variations in model parameters and architectures. 

One focus of the research was robust subspace recovery, a technique for identifying meaningful structures within datasets that are contaminated by outliers. This work introduced a novel method capable of effectively recovering these structures even when outliers dominate. Applications include computer vision tasks like estimating the fundamental matrix, which is critical for accurate 3D reconstructions of environments from surveillance footage.

To address privacy concerns, the project employed differential privacy techniques within robust subspace recovery. By incorporating Gaussian noise into stochastic gradient methods, the research demonstrated how these privacy-preserving methods could maintain accuracy and performance without compromising data security.

The project also enhanced the process of reconstructing 3D structures and estimating camera motion from 2D images, essential for creating spatially accurate models in threat detection scenarios. Two innovative methods addressed synchronization challenges. The first method, designed for synchronizing camera orientations, tolerates high levels of corruption and achieves accurate results without prior initialization. The second method, focused on multi-object matching, introduced a memory-efficient approach to finding correspondences across datasets, achieving faster and more scalable performance than previous techniques.

Another significant contribution was in novelty detection, which involves identifying unusual or unexpected data. The team developed a robust variational autoencoder to address scenarios with heavily corrupted training data, offering both strong theoretical guarantees and impressive empirical results.

Beyond these core outcomes, the project explored other areas, including graph generation using a trainable unpooling layer, fair optimization frameworks, and the modeling of competitive markets. Research into AI agents revealed insights into how they may engage in tacit collusion, providing a deeper understanding of fairness and competition in modern economies.

The broader impacts of the project extended to education and public engagement. All codes and resources developed were made publicly available to facilitate broader use. The project supported the mentorship of a diverse group of postdoctoral, graduate, and undergraduate students. Educational activities included organizing an industrial problems seminar, where industry leaders shared their research and career experiences, and co-organizing a data science seminar. These initiatives prepared students for careers in industry, with talks and resources available online to a wider community. Additionally, the principal investigator facilitated internships for students and created freely accessible resources to help them secure such opportunities.
